title: Web type peeves?
content:
What's your biggest peeve about typography and the internet?   
   
(I'm looking for anything here: from "the way that it is dicussed in online communities like this one," to "I just think that Trebucht looks un-cool," to "my mom has her display defaults all set to courier!")
author: dan_reynolds

comments.content:
Just before anyone else says it, people using Comic Sans inappropriately, usually on business websites.   
   
Anti-Flame Note: Comic Sans isn't a bad font in its own right for the purposes it was intended.

"What's your biggest peeve about typography and the internet?"   
   
That people keep bitching about typography on the internet. ;o)   
   
Seriously, my biggest peeve is when the visual designers think they know the specific type size that works for me and then make it difficult for me to change it.

My biggest peeve right now is not being able to **easily** accomplish **dynamic** relative sizing so when your browser window changes size or elements in the window change size the type will resize too.   
   
Another is the paucity of widely distributed multiplatform type. It's been awhile since Microsoft released their web fonts. Adobe, Macromedia, Apple, MS (again ) could take a run at it, and even greater would be an Alliance of all these companies all distributing the exact same fonts with sw installs and from their websites. For \*nix too! Alternatively all the independent founderies could team up to do the same. Reach is critical and free is critical.

"My biggest peeve right now is not being able to easily accomplish dynamic relative sizing so when your browser window changes size or elements in the window change size the type will resize too."   
   
But, as an end user, why would I want that? FYI, you can have the page elements/objects resize in conjunction with the type by using percentages or ems or other relative measurements. However, I usually find this a usability/accessibility hindrance rather than benefit.

Oops...I take that back...the dynamic page sizing would only work for ems (ie, it has to be a relative measurement based off of the type size.)   
   
Example:   
   
 [http://www.cednc.org/programs/engage/finance/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051129/http:/www.cednc.org/programs/engage/finance/)   
   
(visit the site and then resize your text)

The monotony and crudity of paragraph styling.   
�����Everything is rag right, no first line indent, and a full extra line between paragraphs.   
�����Props to Armin for the centred heads at Speak Up and other virtuosities, but every time I go there I think "this text should be justified!"

Can I have _two_ big ones?   
1) That we're essentially stuck with userside-installed fonts.   
2) That MacOS is taking the full-fuzz road to hell.   
   
hhp

Darrel, I'm well aware of the usability issues that this could present and I am also aware of a lot of issues around the re-sizing of type on the web. FWIW IE can't resize text if it's set at a pixel dimension but Mozilla (and derivatives and Safari can). An of course there is a lot of information in the web development sphere about this.   
   
I just think sometimes it would be nice to say "make this type be 75% of the height of its enclosing box (no matter what the size of that box is) for things like headlines title blocks or section pages, or even things we have never imagined.

"I just think sometimes it would be nice to say "make this type be 75% of the height of its enclosing box "   
   
In shorthand:   
   
div font-size: 12px   
 p font-size: 75%   
/div   
   
or is that not what you meant?

I'll say it. Comic Sans has overstayed its welcome in comics too. This is not to say it's a bad comic font when used as intended; it was obviously designed for U&lc. But cartoonists, in thrall to tradition, invariably set it in ALL CAPS. And ALL CAPS is rather unflattering to Comic Sans.

Stephen,   
   
_Oh no Nick! That is the one thing I love about what the Web has   
done to typography (besides elimination of double-spaces between   
sentences). Justified setting exists, but it is rare - and that   
makes me glad._      
   
Rare?

That a large part of graphic designer's portofolios on the web are done all Flash in separate windows and when they put more than two words (for the 10% of the ones who sometime know how to wrote) of texts on their Flash(y), its so fuzzy and not legible at all.

this probably goes without saying but I still see it everywhere. image text! when the designer is so into their type - decides they absolutely have to use some obscure face but can't feed it to the server - and flattens everything into gifs. extra bothersome when its a transparent gif of text with some custom matte to match the background. no text selection - hell to edit.

\> Flash(y), its so fuzzy and not legible at all.   
   
Yes, very true. That's where [http://www.ultrafonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051129/http:/www.ultrafonts.com/) comes in. :-)   
   
hhp

Darrel:   
_In shorthand: div font-size: 12px/p font-size: 75%/div   
or is that not what you meant?_      
   
Almost but not quite. What I really mean is any font-size **not only** be expressed relative to the base font size stipulated by the system but **have the option to be expressed relative to the size of its containing box** , using % so things would scale as the wndow resized.   
In shorthand:   
   
div height: 50% (of viewport height)   
div p font-size: 75% (of DIV HEIGHT)   
/div   
   
But this **really** is a tangent, and I think you already think I may be out of my mind so I'll just let this go quietly, not hijack the thread.   
   
Jon

Stephen,   
   
_Gerald said: "Rare?"   
   
Yes, justified text is rare on the Web._   
      
   
����������������   
   
Maybe if you told me how it was done it would not be so rare. How do you do that grey?   
   
����������������   
   
_Justified setting exists, but it is rare - and that makes me glad._   
   
So why are you glad, glad because you don't think justified text is valid, or because on the web it just stinks, as does all web typography?   
   
Anyway, how do you do it, and how do you make that type grey?

get annoyed with two things to do   
with flash. 1 � Fuzzy small type,   
especially on 'designer' sites.   
2 � tiny type that I can't make bigger.   
   
Another one is colour. Stupidly   
coloured type on loud backgrounds.   
Very hard to read = close window   
for Kris.

nick, i agree with you about the crude level of paragraph styling. people just stick with the default -- they take the default space above and below a tag, say a \<p\>.   
   
joe public might now be able, through their web building application, to set font, size, colour. and even leading if we are lucky. but its only those that know (and care) that would start to play around with either first line indents or space around paragraphs. just like with dtp...   
   
but i'm glad that we don't see more justified text online. justified text only works when done right (as we all know), which is far beyond the capability of joe public...

Matt,   
   
I can well imagine _joe public_ may have trouble setting justified text on the web. I am a typographer and don't know where to begin.   
   
Fess up, how do you do it?

"Anyway, how do you do it"   
   
\<p\>text\</p\>   
   
and yea, it usually sucks.

Aww...crap. This forum has the worst text parsing I've seen anywhere.   
   
Ok, with fake tags:   
   
(p style="text-align:justify;")put your text here(/p)

Justified text is possible with Cascading Style Sheets (CSS), a major initiative of the WWW consortium.   
   
Dreamweaver implemented it in Version 3, in 1999.   
   
\*\*\*   
   
Stephen: I am not against rag right, or even a lot of rag right. I'd just like a little variety.   
   
\*\*\*   
   
Gerald, the Web is a medium like any other -- when typographers put care and attention into how they use it, that's nice, and occasionally spectacular.

funny that nobody mentioned this in this thread: one of the biggest problems in web-type is that there is no flexible type family for screens\*.   
   
\* flexible type families for print are there since frutiger's revolutionary univers system. there are a lot of other examples of this kind of type families today: stone, rotis, scala, thesis, fedra, fago, zine, compatil and many many others.   
   
well, there \*was\* no flexible type family for screens... the elementar system was designed to finally fill this gap. ;-)   
   
the elementar fonts are being released little by little at ultrafonts. take a look at it � [http://www.ultrafonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051129/http:/www.ultrafonts.com/).   
   
-g.

No flexible type families?   
   
What about Linotype's new Lomo? 37 different weights!   
   
 [http://www.linotype.com/6-2091-6/lomovaluepack.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051129/http:/www.linotype.com/6-2091-6/lomovaluepack.html)   
 [http://www.linotype.com/6-2091-6/lomovaluepack.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051129/http:/www.linotype.com/6-2091-6/lomovaluepack.html)

Hey, Lomo looks pretty tasty. I wonder why they don't show it at actual size though.   
   
Anyway, it's still only 1-bit. That's so 20th century.   
   
hhp

thanks for the link dan, i did not know this font.   
   
but lomo does not have 37 \*weights\* - it has 37 \*variations\*, which is a completely different thing.   
   
the lomo fonts have names which are, for me, confusing - 'zigg', 'butt', 'sall' and so on. the elementar fonts are organised with a nummerical system which is much easier to understand (imo).   
   
and yes, fonts from the elementar system are ultra pixel (grayscale) fonts, what makes a big difference...

Now, I'm just the marketing intern, but I suspect that Lomo is not shown at actual size because its sample was automatically generated, just like all of the text fonts.   
   
Lomo may also be Linotype's only pixel offering to date, hench the lack of special treatment. Also, unlike many other pixel fonts, I think that Linotype hopes that people will use these for print as well.   
   
I'm sorry for calling them "weights." The lingo is already getting to me.

Web peeves.. mine is the use of:   
   
These :: things :: to :: divide :: everything,   
   
just because you can't put more than one space and tabs are too wide. (Resize a 1x1pixel transparent gif, and you've got your space.)

"Most vector screen fonts are crisp in Flash, but for some reason when pulling dynamic text into Flash most of them get fuzzy. The Miniml ones don't"   
   
Hmmm. I use dynamic bitmap fonts all the time, most of the time from Miniml, but don't run into this problem. All about keeping the text field on a whole pixel, but I'm sure you knew that.

\<quote\>   
Web peeves.. mine is the use of:   
   
These :: things :: to :: divide :: everything,   
   
just because you can't put more than one space and tabs are too wide. (Resize a 1x1pixel transparent gif, and you've got your space.)   
\</quote\>   
   
i think its liberating that you can't put double (or multiple) spaces in. liberating the web from the typist style of a double space after a period.   
   
and don't get me started on spacer .gif's = work of the devil IMHO

Sometimes I type a long paragraph, and then think, am I really saying anything? So I'll summarize what I had. ;)   
   
Can anyone provide some links of medium to long length paragraphs of HTML text using indents?   
   
I really haven't thought much about issues using spacers. There's two things I'm aware of. One is that you can see the outline when they are loading, and the other is that they don't resize with text. So that's probably enough to never use them, but what other issues have you run into?

[quote]So that's probably enough to never use them, but what other issues have you run into? [/quote]   
   
It's another hit on the server (albeit a small one). The bigger issue is that if you add spacer images to the HTML, you are mixing the presentantion with the content more than you really need to. Typically, CSS can be used, and, when it is used, it allows the content to remain free of any particular style...meaning it is much more portable and re-usable than markup full of things like spacer images.

"Justified text is possible with Cascading Style Sheets (CSS), a major initiative of the WWW consortium."   
   
As has already been pointed out this can be done. The problem is that hyphenation isn't automatic, you have to insert hyphens manually, which is no use whatsoever.   
   
"For what it's worth, this appears to be a Flash bug, not a fault of the various font makers out there."   
   
That shouldn't be happening, try setting your movieclip holding the text field to 99% (myMC.myText.\_xscale = myMC.myText.\_yscale = 99;)   
   
"If anybody knows of other screen fonts for use with dynamic Flash I'd be happy to know of more."   
   
Personally I favour [http://www.fontsforflash.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051129/http:/www.fontsforflash.com/) particularly FFF corporate, which I've relied on countless times.   
   
What really really drives me mad is the amount of hacks you have to go through just to undo the basic styling (I'm not going to say design as that would imply some level of thought process) applied by a browser. For example, to hang punctuation you need to remove the automatic margins on the blockquote, insert your quote entities and then use a first-line indent of about -0.5em. You end up with 100 odd lines of code just to get to what you can consider unmolested copy. It's just such a runaround that I don't find it surprising that people just don't bother.

Benjie, try   
 [http://www.ultrafonts.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051129/http:/www.ultrafonts.com/)   
instead.
